questiontext.text:
Exercise

Consider \(\displaystyle\int_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr}\), where \(\underline{F} = {@aa@}x^2 y^2 \underline{i} + ({@bb@}x^3 y - {@cc@})\underline{j}\). Find the value of the line integral along each of the paths from \((0,0)\) to \((1,4)\).

  1. \(y = 4x\)

    \(\displaystyle\int_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} =\)[[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]][[feedback:prt1]]

  2. \(y = 4x^2\)

    \(\displaystyle\int_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} =\)[[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]][[feedback:prt2]]

  3. \(y = 4 x^{1/2}\)

    \(\displaystyle\int_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} =\)[[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]][[feedback:prt3]]

  4. \(y = 4x^3\)

    \(\displaystyle\int_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} =\)[[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]][[feedback:prt4]]

generalfeedback.text:
We know that \(\underline{F} = {@aa@}x^2 y^2 \underline{i} + ({@bb@}x^3 y - {@cc@})\underline{j}\), and aim to find the value of the line integral along each of the paths from \((0,0)\) to \((1,4)\):

(a) We know that \(y=4x\) and so aim to write the line integral in terms of \(x\). Parametrising \(\underline{r}\) in terms of \(x\) and then aiming to find \(\underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x}\), we find: \[\begin{aligned} \underline{r} &= x\underline{i}+ (4x)\underline{j}\\ \frac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x} &= \underline{i}+ 4\underline{j}\\ \underline{F} &= {@aa@}x^2 (4x)^2 \underline{i} + ({@bb@}x^3 (4x) - {@cc@})\underline{j}\\ &= {@16*aa@}x^4 \underline{i} + ({@4*bb@}x^4 - {@cc@})\underline{j} \\ \underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x} &= {@16*aa@}x^4 + {@16*bb@}x^4 - {@4*cc@}\\ &= {@16*aa + 16*bb@}x^4 - {@4*cc@} \end{aligned}\]

Therefore, we may solve the line integral as follows: \[\begin{aligned} \int_C \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} &= \int^1_0 \underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x}\ \\ &= \int^1_0 {@16*aa + 16*bb@}x^4 - {@4*cc@}\ \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \left[{@(16*aa + 16*bb)/5@}x^5 - {@4*cc@}x \right]^1_0\\ &={@(16*aa + 16*bb)/5@}(1)^5 - {@4*cc@}(1) \\ &= {@(16*aa + 16*bb)/5 - 4*cc@} \end{aligned}\]

(b) \(C_2\) : We know that \(y\) follows the parabola \(y = 4x^2\), and so we rewrite the line integral in terms of \(x\) to solve.

We again aim to write the line integral in terms of \(x\). Parametrising \(\underline{r}\) in terms of \(x\) and then aiming to find \(\underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x}\), we find: \[\begin{aligned} \underline{r} &= x\underline{i}+ 4x^2\underline{j}\\ \frac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x} &= \underline{i}+ 8x\underline{j}\\ \underline{F} &= {@aa@}x^2 (4x^2)^2 \underline{i} + ({@bb@}x^3 (4x^2) - {@cc@})\underline{j}\\ &= {@16*aa@}x^6 \underline{i} + ({@4*bb@}x^5 - {@cc@})\underline{j}\\ \underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x} &={@16*aa@}x^6 + {@32*bb@}x^6 - {@8*cc@}x\\ &={@16*aa+32*bb@}x^6 - {@8*cc@}x. \end{aligned}\]

Therefore, we may solve the line integral as follows: \[\begin{aligned} \int_{C_2} \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} &= \int^1_0 \underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x}\ \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \int^1_0 {@16*aa+32*bb@}x^6 - {@8*cc@}x\ \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \left[{@(16*aa+32*bb)/7@}x^7 - {@4*cc@}x^2\right]^1_0\\ &= \left({@(16*aa+32*bb)/7@}(1)^7 - {@4*cc@}(1)^2\right) \\ &= {@(16*aa+32*bb)/7- 4*cc@} \end{aligned}\]

(C) \(C_3\) : We know that \(y\) follows the curve \(y = 4x^\frac{1}{2}\), and so we rewrite the line integral in terms of \(x\) to solve.

We again aim to write the line integral in terms of \(x\). Parametrising \(\underline{r}\) in terms of \(x\) and then aiming to find \(\underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x}\), we find: \[\begin{aligned} \underline{r} &= x\underline{i}+ 4x^\frac{1}{2}\underline{j}\\ \frac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x} &= \underline{i}+ 2x^{-\frac{1}{2}}\underline{j}\\ \underline{F} &= {@aa@}x^2 (4x^\frac{1}{2})^2 \underline{i} + ({@bb@}x^3 (4x^\frac{1}{2}) - {@cc@})\underline{j}\\ &= {@16*aa@}x^3 \underline{i} + ({@4*bb@}x^\frac{7}{2} - {@cc@})\underline{j}\\ \underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x} &= {@16*aa@}x^3 + {@8*bb@}x^3 - {@2*cc@} x^{-\frac{1}{2}}\\ &={@16*aa+8*bb@}x^3 - {@2*cc@}x^{-\frac{1}{2}}. \end{aligned}\]

Therefore, we may solve the line integral as follows: \[\begin{aligned} \int_{C_2} \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} &= \int^1_0 \underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x}\ \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \int^1_0 {@16*aa+8*bb@}x^3 - {@2*cc@}x^{-\frac{1}{2}}\ \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \left[{@4*aa+2*bb@}x^4 - {@4*cc@}x^{\frac{1}{2}}\right]^1_0\\ &= \left({@4*aa+2*bb@}(1)^4 - {@4*cc@}(1)^{\frac{1}{2}}\right) \\ &= {@4*aa+2*bb - 4*cc@} \end{aligned}\]

(D) \(C_4\) : We know that \(y\) follows the cubic \(y = 4x^3\), and so we rewrite the line integral in terms of \(x\) to solve.

We again aim to write the line integral in terms of \(x\). Parametrising \(\underline{r}\) in terms of \(x\) and then aiming to find \(\underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x}\), we find: \[\begin{aligned} \underline{r} &= x\underline{i}+ 4x^3\underline{j}\\ \frac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x} &= \underline{i}+ 12x^2\underline{j}\\ \underline{F} &= {@aa@}x^2 (4x^3)^2 \underline{i} + ({@bb@}x^3 (4x^3) - {@cc@})\underline{j}\\ &= {@16*aa@}x^8 \underline{i} + ({@4*bb@}x^6 - {@cc@})\underline{j}\\ \underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x} &={@16*aa@}x^8 + {@48*bb@}x^8 - {@12*cc@}x^2\\ &={@16*aa+48*bb@}x^8 - {@12*cc@}x^2. \end{aligned}\]

Therefore, we may solve the line integral as follows: \[\begin{aligned} \int_{C_2} \underline{F} \cdot \underline{dr} &= \int^1_0 \underline{F}\cdot\dfrac{\mathrm{d}\underline{r}}{\mathrm{d}x}\ \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \int^1_0 {@16*aa+48*bb@}x^8 - {@12*cc@}x^2\ \mathrm{d}x \\ &= \left[{@(16*aa+48*bb)/9@}x^9 - {@4*cc@}x^3\right]^1_0\\ &= \left({@(16*aa+48*bb)/9@}(1)^9 - {@4*cc@}(1)^3\right) \\ &= {@(16*aa+48*bb)/9- 4*cc@} \end{aligned}\]

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

qtest.description: Test case assuming the teacher's input gets full marks.
